1.0        ENVIRONMENTAL CHECKLIST/INITIAL STUDY 

           Peninsular Plaza Project 

 
 
Project Title:                    Peninsular Plaza Project 
 
Lead Agency:                      City of San Bruno 
 
Location:                         400­418 San Mateo Avenue 
                                  San Bruno, California 94066 
  
Applicant:                        Conceptual Investment & Management, Inc. 
                                  280 12th Street 
                                  Oakland, CA 94607 
 
Existing (1986) General Plan 
Land Use Designation:             Neighborhood Community Commercial 
                 
Future (2008) General Plan 
Land Use Designation:             Downtown Mixed Use 
 
Existing Zoning:                  Central Business District/R2, Low Density Residential District 
 
Existing Onsite Land Uses:        Vacant cinema structure, vacant commercial buildings (formerly bars)  
 
Surrounding Land Uses:            The  project  site  is  surrounded  by  residential  uses  to  the  east,  and 
                                  commercial uses to the north, south, and west.  
 
Description of Project:           See attached Project Description in Section 3 of this Initial Study.  
 
Interested and  
Responsible Agencies:             Bay Area Air Quality Management District; 
                                  San Francisco Bay Regional Water Quality Board. 
                                   




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                  1                         Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                       June 2008 
 


2.0        INTRODUCTION 

2.1        Initial Study 

           Pursuant  to  Section  15063  of  the  State  California  Environmental  Quality  Act  (CEQA)  Guidelines 
           (Title 14,  California  Code  of  Regulations,  Sections  15000  et  seq.),  an  Initial  Study  is  a  preliminary 
           environmental  analysis  that  is  used  by  the  lead  agency  as  a  basis  for  determining  whether  an 
           EIR,  a  Mitigated  Negative  Declaration,  or  a  Negative  Declaration  is  required  for  a  project.  The 
           State  CEQA  Guidelines  require  that  an  Initial  Study  contain  a  project  description;  a  description  of 
           environmental  setting;  an  identification  of  environmental  effects  by  checklist  or  other  similar 
           form;  an  explanation  of  environmental  effects;  a  discussion  of  mitigation  for  significant 
           environmental  effects;  an  evaluation  of  the  project's  consistency  with  existing,  applicable  land 
           use controls; and the names of persons who prepared the study. 

           Public  Resources  Code  Section  21080(a)  states  that  analysis  of  a  project's  environmental  impacts 
           is  required  for  any  "discretionary  projects  proposed  to  be  carried  out  or  approved  by  public 
           agencies,  including,  but  not  limited  to,  the  enactment  and  amendment  of  zoning  ordinances."  In 
           this  case,  and  pursuant  to  Public  Resources  Code  Section  21080,  the  City  of  San  Bruno  has 
           determined  that  an  Initial  Study  is  required  to  determine  whether  there  is  substantial  evidence 
           that implementation of the Peninsular Plaza Project would result in environmental impacts. 

           State  CEQA  Guidelines  Section  15064  requires  that  when  an  Initial  Study  identifies  significant 
           environmental  impacts,  the  Lead  Agency  must  prepare  an  EIR.  However,  State  CEQA  Guidelines 
           Section  15070  provides  that  if  all  of  the  impacts  can  be  mitigated  to  a  less  than  significant  level, 
           the  Lead  Agency  may  instead  prepare  a  Mitigated  Negative  Declaration  (MND)  whereby 
           mitigation  measures  are  created  as  a  condition  of  project  approval.  For  the  purposes  of  this 
           evaluation,  it  has  been  determined  that  a  Mitigated  Negative  Declaration  is  appropriate  for  the 
           project because all identified impacts can be mitigated to a less than significant level. 

2.2        Public and Agency Review 

           This  Initial  Study  and  proposed  MND  will  be  circulated  for  public  and  agency  review  from  June 
           9, 2008 to July 9, 2008. Copies of this document are available for review at the following locations 
           and online at http://www.sanbruno.ca.gov 

           ·     San Bruno City Hall, 567 El Camino Real, San Bruno, CA 94066 
           ·     San Bruno Library, 701 Angus Avenue West, San Bruno, CA 94066 
            
2.3        Project Approvals 

           As  a  public  agency  principally  responsible  for  approving  or  carrying  out  the  proposed  project, 
           the City of San Bruno (City) is the Lead Agency under CEQA and is responsible for certifying the 
           adequacy  of  the  environmental  document  and  approving  the  proposed  project.  It  is  anticipated 
           that the City Planning Commission and City Council will consider the proposed project in 2008. 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                           2                             Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                    June 2008 
                                                                                                        2.0  Introduction 


2.4        Organization of the Initial Study 

           This Initial Study is organized into the following sections: 

           Section  1   Project  Information:  provides  summary  background  information  about  the  proposed 
           project, including project location, lead agency, and contact information.  

           Section  2    Introduction:  summarizes  the  scope  of  the  document,  the  project's  review  and 
           approval processes, and the document's organization. 

           Section 3  Project Description: presents a description of the proposed project, including the need 
           for the project, the project's objectives, and the elements included in the project. 

           Section  4    Environmental  Factors  Potentially  Affected:  addresses  whether  this  Initial  Study 
           identifies  any  environmental  factors  that  involve  a  significant  or  potentially  significant  impact 
           that cannot be reduced to a less than significant level. 

           Section 5  Determination: indicates whether impacts associated with the proposed project would 
           be significant and what, if any, additional environmental documentation is required. 

           Section  6   Evaluation  of  Environmental  Impacts:  contains  the  Environmental  Checklist  form  for 
           each  resource  area.  The  checklist  is  used  to  assist  in  evaluating  the  potential  environmental 
           impacts  of  the  proposed  project.  This  section  also  presents  a  background  summary  for  each 
           resource area, and an explanation of all checklist answers. 

           Section  7  ­  Mandatory  Findings  of  Significance:  indicates  whether  implementation  of  the 
           proposed project would result in significant environmental impacts. 

           Section  8  ­  Sources  of  Information  Used  in  Preparing  Initial  Study:  lists  references  used  in  the 
           preparation of this document. 

           Section  9    Report  Preparers:  lists  the  names  of  individuals  involved  in  the  preparation  of  this 
           document. 

 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                        3                           Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                               June 2008 
                                                                                                                                  


3.0        PROJECT DESCRIPTION 

3.1        Introduction 

           The  City  of  San  Bruno  (City)  is  located  in  San  Mateo  County,  and  is  bordered  by  the  San 
           Francisco  International  Airport  (SFO)  to  the  east,  the  City  of  Millbrae  to  the  south,  the  City  of 
           Pacifica  and  unincorporated  San  Mateo  County  to  the  west,  and  the  City  of  South  San  Francisco 
           to  the  north  (See  Figure  1,  Location  Map:  400418  San  Mateo  Avenue).  The  City  has  many 
           transportation  routes  that  run  through  it,  including  Interstates  280  and  380,  Highway  101,  the 
           Bay  Area  Rapid  Transit  (BART)  and  a  BART Station, a commuter rail line (Caltrain) and Caltrain 
           station, and San Mateo County Transit District (SamTrans) bus services.  

           The  project  site  is  located  in  the  City's  Redevelopment  Plan  Area.  Development  patterns  in  the 
           broader  project  area  occurred  with  some  degree  of  irregularity  due  to  the  City's  early  founding 
           (1914)  and  proximity  to  SFO.  A  portion  of  the  City's  core  commercial  area  declined  over  time  in 
           terms  of  its  commercial  viability  and  vitality.  Through  a  series  of  planning  activities,  the  City 
           designated  the  commercial  core  and  some  surrounding  lands  as  redevelopment  areas  that  could 
           be  revitalized  to  improve  the  local  economy  and  provide  a  more  cohesive  City  identity.  The  City 
           adopted  its  Redevelopment  Plan  in  1999,  and  the  project  site  is  within  the  Plan  Area 
           (See Figure 2, City of San Bruno Redevelopment Plan Area). 

3.2        Project Summary 

           The project applicant is proposing to demolish the former El Camino Cinema and three adjoining 
           commercial  buildings  and  construct  in  their  place  a  mixeduse,  threestory  commercial  and 
           residential  building  with  an  integrated  multilevel  parking  structure  (see  Figure  3A3E, 
           Conceptual  Site  Plan).  The  former  San  Bruno  Cinema  building  is  currently  vacant  except  for  a 
           small  dental  office  that  would  be  vacated  prior  to  project  implementation.  The  proposed  project 
           would  contain  approximately  15,000  square  feet  (sf)  of  commercial  space  at  the  ground  level 
           fronting  San  Mateo  Avenue,  48  residential  units  above  the  commercial  space,  an  interior 
           courtyard  for  the  benefit  of  the  project's  residents,  and  a  152space  parking  structure  facility 
           integrated within the building. 

           The current land uses on the project site are vacant commercial space and one dental office. In the 
           past, the site has been used for a variety of commercial and office uses. The exterior of the cinema 
           building  has  been  altered  over  time  to  accommodate  a  variety  of  tenants.  The  other  two 
           commercial  buildings  adjacent  to  the  cinema  are  onestory  midcentury  construction  with 
           frontages  along  San  Mateo  Avenue.  This  has  resulted  in  adjacent  commercial  buildings  that  lack 
           aesthetic  and  visual  unity.  The  exterior  features  associated  with  the  cinema  building  dating  from 
           its  initial  construction  and  use  as  a  cinema  have  been  lost  due  to  the  multiple  exterior 
           modifications.  The  proposed  project  would  replace  the  existing  building  with  a  threestory 
           mixeduse commercial and residential development that would visually enhance the existing site 
           and provide an improved visual anchor and entry to the City's downtown commercial area.

                                                                                                 3.0  Project Description 


3.3        Project Location and Surrounding Uses 

           The  project  site  is  bounded  by  San  Mateo  Avenue,  Taylor  Avenue,  and  Mastick  Avenue  in  the 
           southern  portion  of  the  City's  downtown  area.  The  project  site  is  surrounded  by  residential  uses 
           to  the  east,  and  commercial  uses  to  the  north,  west,  and  south.  The  project  site  is  completely 
           developed  with  existing  structures  and  a  parking  lot.  There  are  several  ornamental  trees  on  the 
           site,  including  pine  and  eucalyptus.  The  site  is  characterized  by  a  slight  westtoeast  slope,  with 
           the  eastern  portion  of  the  site  approximately  10  feet  lower  than  the  western  portion.  The  project 
           site is approximately 1 acre in size (See Figure 3A).  

3.4        Project Site Zoning 

           The  project  site  is  zoned  Central  Business  District  (CBD)  and  LowDensity  Residential  (R2). 
           Based  on  the  County  Assessor's  parcel  record,  the  net  parcel  area  is  42,348  square  feet.  Utilizing 
           the  density  of  one  unit  per  1,000  feet,  as  outlined  in  the  CBD  description,  there  could  be  a 
           maximum  of  42  multifamily  units  on  the  upper  levels  and  a  variety  of  commercial  uses  on  the 
           ground level.  

3.5        Affordable Housing 

           The  City  relies  on  the  California  State  density  bonus  law,  established  by  SB  1818,  to  encourage 
           the  development  of  affordable  units.  The  applicant  would  provide  20  percent  of  the  residential 
           units  (8  units)  at  a  price  affordable  to  moderateincome  citizens  (as  determined  annually  by  the 
           Department  of  Housing  and  Community  Development).  As  a  result  of  this  affordable  housing 
           component,  the  applicant  has  requested  a  density  bonus  of  6  units,  for  a  total  of  48  units.  The 
           density  bonus  is  a  discretionary  action,  and  is  therefore  part  of  the  approval  process  for  the 
           project,  consistent  with  the  conditions  of  the  density  bonus  program.  Both  the  market  rate  and 
           moderateincome  units  would  count  toward  partial  fulfillment  of  the  City's  Regional  Housing 
           Allocation, as outlined in the City's Housing Element.  

3.6        Project Characteristics 

           A detailed description of the project characteristics is provided below. 

3.6.1      Project Design and Landscaping Features 

           Building Design 

           The  project  design  reflects  Europeaninspired  pedestrian  friendly  streetscape  architectural  style, 
           which was guided by the City's Redevelopment Plan. The project's design is intended to produce 
           a building design that improves the aesthetics of the built corridor along San Mateo Avenue. The 
           proposed  project  design  includes  a  rounded  50foottall  columnar  structure  at  the  intersection  of 
           San Mateo Avenue and Taylor Avenue.  

           The  approximately  15,000  sf  of  groundlevel  commercial  space  would  front  on  San  Mateo 
           Avenue,  with  the  152space  offstreet  parking  area  for  the  project  located  in  a  twolevel  structure 
           located behind the commercial portion of the project (See discussion of offstreet parking below). 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                        12                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                 June 2008 
                                                                                                 3.0  Project Description 


           The  48  residential  units  would  include  a  mix  of  studios, 1, 2 and 3bedroom condominium flats 
           (singlelevel)  and  multilevel  loft  units.  The  units  would  be  located  above  the  commercial  space 
           and  parking  structure.  The  project  design  includes  a  central  private  courtyard  that  would  be 
           reserved  for  the  use  and  enjoyment  of  the  project's  residents.  Each  of  the  residential  units  would 
           have  a  balcony  facing  either  outward  to  the  exterior  of  the  project  or  inward  toward  the  central 
           courtyard.  The  project  would  also  include  a  community  room  for  use  by  the  project's  residents. 
           The  main  pedestrian  entrance  to  the  residential  portion  of  the  project  would  be  on  San  Mateo 
           Avenue. 

           Air  handling  units  would  be  located  on  the  flat  portion  of  the  building's  roof  surrounded  by  a 
           parapet wall to visually shield the equipment from view as well as to provide noise attenuation. 

           The  project  design  takes  advantage  of  the  project  site's  westtoeast  downward  slope  by  placing 
           the parking levels at the eastern, or lower portion of the site. This allows the covered parking that 
           is  atgrade  with  Mastick  Avenue  to  extend  approximately  500  feet  to  the  middle  of  the  project 
           site,  placing  it  adjacent  to  the  proposed  retail  space.  The  additional  underground  parking  level 
           would  be  easily  integrated  into  the  project  site  and  would  extend  underneath  the  entire  project 
           footprint.  

           Colors and Materials 

           The  exterior  of  the  building  would  utilize  various  materials  to  break  up  the  visual  bulk  of  the 
           building.  Brick  veneer  and  cement  plaster  would  be  the  main  exterior  wall  materials,  and  would 
           be  a  combination  of  three  complimentary  muted  colors.  A  dark  red  brick  would  be  the  primary 
           color and would be accented by creamcolored cement plaster and dark grey painted metal. Door 
           and window frames would be painted metal. Exterior balconies off of the residential units would 
           be constructed of painted metal with a decorative soffit, or cover, of a contrasting color. Exposed, 
           unfinished concrete would be used and visible near the parking structure entrance. 

           Lighting 

           Internal  lighting  would  utilize  indirect  sunlight  where  appropriate  and  operable  shades  on 
           exterior  windows  to  reduce  bright  light  and  glare  at  various  times  of  day.  Exterior  lighting 
           features  would  be  implemented  at  both  the  retail  and  residential  entrances,  in  the  proposed 
           parking  lot  structure,  and  along  the  sidewalks  of  the  project  site.  Primary  exterior  lighting 
           fixtures  would  be  wallmounted  with  frosted  glass  covers.  Additional  security  exterior  lighting 
           would be provided near all doorways and would utilize brighter light bulbs for safety. 

           Landscaping 

           Approximately  19  trees  would  be  planted  along  the  perimeter  sidewalk  of  the  proposed  project. 
           For  a  detailed  description  of  all  plants  and  the  approximate  location  of  landscaping  included  in 
           the  project,  please  see  Figure  4,  Landscaping  Plan.  The  trees  would  be  planted  into  the  ground 
           with  a  grate  covering  their exposed soil to protect the root systems. There are three types of trees 
           proposed  along  the  exterior,  myrtle  trees,  New  Zealand  Christmas  trees,  and  pear  trees.  There 
           would  be  a  series  of  raised  planters  along  the  Taylor  Avenue  exterior  and  the  Mastic  Avenue 
           exterior.  Typical  plants  in  these  planters  would  be  vines,  rosemary,  bamboo,  flax,  lavender,  and 
           Japanese boxwood.  


Impact Sciences, Inc.                                        13                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                 June 2008 
                                                                                                 3.0  Project Description 


           Landscaping  would  also  be  provided  in  a  private  open  space  area  for  residents  on  the  second 
           level  of  the  project.  This  open  space  area  would  consist  of  14  small  trees  and  several  planters 
           with perennial flowers. 

3.6.2      Vehicular Access, Parking, and Pedestrian Access 

           Vehicular  access  to  the  site  would  be  via  an  entrance  on  Mastick  Avenue.  The  proposed  project 
           would provide two levels of parking, one atgrade level with Mastic Avenue for the benefit of the 
           onsite commercial uses and one restricted access subterranean level for the project residents. The 
           atgrade  parking  level  would  provide  48  parking  spaces  whereas  the  underground  level  would 
           provide 104 spaces. 

           The  applicant  has  proposed  the  provision  of  152  parking  spaces,  including  5  spaces  designed  to 
           be consistent with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) standards. As part of the proposed 
           project,  the  applicant  is  seeking  approval  of  shared  parking  between  the  commercial  and 
           residential  uses.  The  City  parking  requirements  for  the  project  site  indicate  that  60  parking 
           spaces  are  required  to  support  the  commercial  uses.  For  the  residential  uses,  the  City  would 
           require  101  parking  spaces.  Therefore,  the  total  required  parking spaces would be 161. However, 
           the  applicant  is  proposing  152  spaces,  which  does  not  meet  the  City's  parking  requirement.  The 
           applicant  is  seeking  approval  of  a  reduction  from  the  City's  parking  standard  due  to  the  higher 
           density housing and provision of affordable housing. These components of the project allow it to 
           fall  under  the  purview  of  the  State  density  bonus  law  which  allows  for  a  reduction  from  the 
           City's Parking Ordinance.  

           There  would  be  at  least  three  pedestrian  entrances  to  the  building  along  the  retail  storefronts  of 
           San  Mateo  Avenue  and  an  exclusive  residential  entrance  also  along  San  Mateo  Avenue.  The  at
           grade  parking  level  would  provide  a  pedestrian  exit  to  San  Mateo  Avenue  as  this  parking  level 
           would be designated for commercial parking. The underground parking level would have access 
           to  the  residential  area  on  the  second  and  third  stories  through  a  stairwell  and  elevator  located 
           near  the  Taylor  Avenue  project  boundary  because  the  underground  level  would  be  restricted  to 
           residents  only.  Additionally,  the  underground  parking  level  would  have  a  restricted  access 
           stairwell exiting to San Mateo Avenue.  

3.6.3      Infrastructure 

           Infrastructure  improvements  would  be  necessary  to  provide  water,  sanitary  sewer,  and  storm 
           drainage  services  to  the  site.  Domestic  water  is  currently  available  to  the  site  via  an  existing 
           8inch  highpressure  water  main  located  within  San  Mateo  Avenue,  with  a  1inch  lateral 
           extension to the site. The existing water main would be upgraded to allow for additional capacity 
           and  extended  50  feet  east  to  provide  sufficient  potable  and  fire  suppression  service  to  the  new 
           land uses, consistent with City requirements.  

           A  new  sanitary  sewer  connection  would  be  required  to  connect  to  the  existing  6inch  sanitary 
           sewer  main  located  within  San  Mateo  Avenue.  An  onsite  stormwater  system  would  be 
           constructed  to  collect  stormwater  and  discharge  it  to  the  existing  storm  drainage  system  within 
           San Mateo Avenue. 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                        15                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                 June 2008 
                                                                                               3.0  Project Description 


3.7        Project Population 

           The  estimated  resident  population  of  the  project  would  be  132  people  for  the  48  units,  based  on 
           the California Department of Finance's E5 Population and Housing Estimates 1 (January 1, 2007).  

3.8        Construction Schedule 

           Project  construction  is  anticipated  to  begin  in  spring  2009,  and  continue  for  approximately  20 
           months. The project is anticipated to be completed and ready for occupancy at the end of 2010. 

3.9        Approvals Requested 

           Architectural  Review  Permit  The  proposed  project  design  would  require  an  architectural 
           review permit. 

           Zone Change ­ The proposed project would change the onsite zoning from R2 to CBD. 

           Tentative  Map  ­  Pursuant  to  the  Subdivison  Map  Act,  approval  of  the  tentative  map  would  be 
           required. 

           Density Increase ­ Pursuant to the State Density Bonus Law, the proposed density increases and 
           associated  incentives  would  require  approval  to  allow  increased  density  and  reduced  parking 
           spaces. 

           Tree  Removal  Permit   A  tree  removal  permit  would  be  requested  as  three  trees  on  the  project 
           site proposed for removal are considered Heritage Trees pursuant to City Code Section 8.25.020. 

 




                                                           
1  The City's median household size is 2.74 persons.

6.0        EVALUATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS 

           This  section  includes  an  evaluation  of  impacts  based  on  the  State  CEQA  Guidelines  Appendix  G 
           Environmental  Checklist,  adapted  to  reflect  the  significance  thresholds  adopted  by  the  City  of 
           San  Bruno.  Each  checklist  item  is  explained  in  the  discussion  following  the  checklist  and,  if 
           necessary,  mitigation  measures  are  provided  to  reduce  impacts  to  a  less  than  significant  level.  In 
           accordance  with  CEQA,  all  answers  take  into  account  the  whole  of  the  action,  including  on  and 
           offsite effects, direct and indirect effects, and effects from both construction and operation of any 
           new development. 

           Each checklist criterion is marked to identify whether there is an environmental impact.  

           ·     A "No Impact" response indicates that there is no impact.  
           ·     A  "Less  Than  Significant  Impact"  response  means  that  while  there  is  some  impact,  the 
                 impact is below the threshold of significance defined by the City.  
           ·     A  "Less  Than  Significant  Impact  with  Mitigation"  response  indicates  that  a  new  impact  has 
                 been  identified  in  the  course  of  this  analysis  and  new  mitigation  measures  have  been 
                 provided  in  this  Initial  Study  to  reduce  the  potentially  significant  impact  to  a  less  than 
                 significant level. 
           ·     A  "Potentially  Significant  Impact"  response  indicates  that  a  new  impact  has  been  identified 
                 in  the  course  of  this  analysis  and  further  analysis  is  required  to  determine  if  mitigation 
                 measures  could  be  imposed  on  the  project  to  reduce  the  impact  to  a  less  than  significant 
                 level.  
           If  a  significant  impact  is  identified  that  could  not  be  reduced  to  a  less  than  significant  level,  the 
           box  "Potential  Significant  Impact"  would  be  checked.  According  to  CEQA,  if  such  an  impact 
           were  identified,  an  Initial  Study  would  not  be  sufficient  to  approve  the  proposed  project,  and  an 
           Environmental Impact Report (EIR) would be necessary. No such impacts have been identified in 
           the course of preparing this Initial Study. 

 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                           19                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                    June 2008 
                                                                              6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


6.1        Aesthetics 

                                                                                          Less than 
                                                                          Potentially     Significant     Less than 
                                                                          Significant     with Project    Significant    No 
                                                                          Impact          Mitigation      Impact         Impact 
     
                                                                                                                          
    AESTHETICS  Would the project: 

    a)  Have a substantial adverse effect on a scenic vista?                                                                     

    b)  Substantially  damage  scenic  resources,  including, 
        but  not  limited  to,  trees,  rock  outcroppings,  and                                                                 
        historic buildings within a state scenic highway? 

    c)  Substantially  degrade  the  existing  visual  character 
        or quality of the site and its surroundings? 
                                                                                                                                 

    d)  Create  a  new  source  of  substantial  light  or  glare, 
        which  would  adversely  affect  day  or  nighttime                                                                      
        views in the area? 

 
DISCUSSION: 

a.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  The  City  of  San  Bruno  (City)  General  Plan  identifies  existing  and 
           potential  scenic  corridors  as  well  as  street  beautification  projects  in  the  City  as  scenic  resources. 
           No  other  scenic  resources  or  vistas  are  identified  within  the  City.  The  nearest  designated  scenic 
           corridor  to  the  project  site  is  Crystal  Springs  Road.  The  portion  of  this  road  that  is  designated  as 
           mile  from  the  project  site,  to  the  San  Bruno  City  Park,  which  is  approximately  1,500  feet  west  of 
           the  project  site.  Given  the  existing  elevation  of  Crystal  Springs  Road  near  the  project  site  and  the 
           density  of  homes  to  the  west  of  the  site,  longrange  views  from  the  designated  scenic  corridor  of 
           the  site  are  not  readily  available.  Given  that  existing  views  for  the  public  from  a  designated 
           scenic  corridor  do  not  afford  views  of  the  project  site,  implementation  of  the  proposed  project 
           would not have a substantial adverse effect on a scenic vista. Therefore, this impact is considered 
           less than significant. 

b.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  The  California  Department  of  Transportation  administers 
           California's  Scenic  Highways  Program.  Designated  California  Scenic  Highways  in  the  vicinity  of 
           the  project  site  include  State  Route  35  (SR  35  or  Skyline  Boulevard)  and  Interstate  280  (I280) 
           (Caltrans  2007).  SR  35  is  a  designated  Scenic  Highway  from  the  Santa  Cruz  County  line  to  State 
           Route 92, south of the project site. The project site is roughly 1.5 miles east of SR 35; however, the 
           project  site  is  not  visible  from  this  roadway  due  to  intervening  land  uses  and  differences  in 
           elevation.  I280  is  a  designated  Scenic  Highway  from  the  Santa  Clara  County  line  to  the  San 
           Bruno  city  limit,  and  is  roughly  1  mile  east  of  the  project  site.  Given  the  distance  and  existing 
           topography  from  this  freeway  to  the  project  site,  views  for  motorists  would  not  be  obscured  by 
           the proposed project. The project site does not contain, nor is it in the immediate vicinity of scenic 
           resources  such  as  rock  outcroppings  or  any  designated  historic  buildings.  Please  see  Section  6.5, 


Impact Sciences, Inc.                                          20                             Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                    June 2008 
                                                                           6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


           Cultural Resources, for the historical evaluation of the existing building on the project site. While 
           the  project  would  remove  some  trees  along  the  sidewalks  and  existing  parking  lot,  it  would  not 
           substantially alter the visual environment from the removal of such trees. Therefore, the project's 
           impact would be less than significant. 

c.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  The  project  site  is  located  in  a  builtup  urban  area,  in  the  vicinity 
           of existing detached singlefamily homes and commercial land uses. The proposed project would 
           replace  an  existing  threestory  cinema  structure,  as  well  as  two  smaller  commercial  buildings 
           along  San  Mateo  Avenue.  The  existing  cinema  commercial  building  on  the  project  site  is 
           approximately 48 feet at its highest point, which includes an elevated eastern portion as well as a 
           façade  on  the  San  Mateo  Avenue  frontage.  The  existing  visual  character  of  these  buildings  lacks 
           continuity  given  the  various  uses  that  have  occupied  the  buildings  and  the  lack  of  architectural 
           unity.  The  proposed  project  would  construct  an  approximately  50foottall  building  that 
           minimally  increase  the  height  of  the  existing  structure  at  the  cinema  site,  given  the  existing 
           structure's  48foot  height.  The  proposed  project  would  be  subject  to  the  City's  Architectural 
           Design  Review.  There  would  be  a  more  substantial  increase  in  height  where  the  two  former  bars 
           are  located.  Currently,  these  buildings  are  approximately  16  feet  tall.  However,  the  proposed 
           project  would  implement  a  new  threestory  building  that  would  have  a  contemporary  design  to 
           create  visual  interest  and  as  well  as  a  cohesive  structure.  The  proposed  project  would  also 
           improve  the  visual  gateway  to  the  City's  downtown  redevelopment  area  for  pedestrians  and 
           motorists traveling north along San Mateo Avenue. 

           The  project  would  result  in  improvements  to  the  site,  including  removal  of  outdated  and  vacant 
           commercial  structures.  The  project  would  also  add  landscaping  along  the  project  sidewalks. 
           Therefore, while changes to visual character on the site would occur, these changes would not be 
           substantially adverse. Therefore, the project's impact would be less than significant. 

d.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  The  project  site  is  located  in  a  builtup  commercial  and  residential 
           area,  with  existing  commercial  uses  to  the  north,  west,  and  south,  and  singlefamily  homes 
           located  to  the  east.  Nearby  streets  provide  sources  of  lighting.  Existing  uses  on  the  project  site 
           generate  some  exterior  lighting  on  the  building  as  well  as  the  parking  area.  New  mixeduse 
           development  proposed  as  part  of  the  project  would  generate  light  and  glare  associated  with 
           exterior  lighting  for  design  and  security  purposes.  However,  exterior  lighting  throughout  the 
           project  site  would  utilize  fixtures  designed  to  minimize  light  spillage  and  would  direct  light 
           downwards  to  not  further  intrude  into  the  nighttime  sky.  Because  the  project  is  within  an  urban 
           setting,  the  increases  in  light  attributed  to  the  project  would  not  be  considered  substantial  and 
           would not adversely affect day or nighttime views in the area; and therefore the impact would be 
           less  than  significant.  The  following  mitigation  measures  would  be  implemented  to  ensure  that 
           the  increase  in  lighting  associated  with  the  proposed  project  does  not  cause  adverse  effects 
           related to increased light and glare. 

           Mitigation  Measure  VIS1:  To  minimize  light  and  glare,  low  profile  and  lowintensity  lighting 
           directed downward shall be used for the exterior facades and all security lighting; 

           Mitigation  Measure  VIS2:  Shielded  fixtures  shall  be  used  on  all  exterior  fixtures  to  minimize 
           glare produced by lighting onsite. 

 


Impact Sciences, Inc.                                         21                           Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                 June 2008 
                                                                             6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


6.2        Agricultural Resources 

                                                                                        Less than 
                                                                         Potentially    Significant     Less than 
                                                                         Significant    with Project    Significant    No 
                                                                         Impact         Mitigation      Impact         Impact 
     
                                                                                                                        
    AGRICULTURAL  RESOURCES    In  determining 
    whether impacts to agricultural resources are significant 
    environmental  effects,  lead  agencies  may  refer  to  the 
    California  Agricultural  Land  Evaluation  and  Site 
    Assessment  Model  (1997)  prepared  by  the  California 
    Dept.  of  Conservation  as  an  optional  model  to  use  in 
    assessing  impacts  on  agriculture  and  farmland.  Would 
    the project: 

    a)  Convert  Prime  Farmland,  Unique  Farmland,  or 
        Farmland  of  Statewide  Importance  (Farmland),  as 
        shown  on  the  maps  prepared  pursuant  to  the 
        Farmland  Mapping  and  Monitoring  Program  of  the 
                                                                                                                               
        California  Resources  Agency,  to  nonagricultural 
        use? 

    b)  Conflict  with  existing  zoning  for  agricultural  use,  or 
        a Williamson Act contract? 
                                                                                                                               

    c)  Involve  other  changes  in  the  existing  environment, 
        which,  due  to  their  location  or  nature,  could  result                                                           
        in conversion of Farmland, to nonagricultural use? 
 
DISCUSSION: 

a.­c.      No  Impact.  The  project  site  is  located  in  a  developed  area.  The  site  is  designated  as 
           Neighborhood/Commercial  by  the  General  Plan,  and  is  zoned  CBD  and  R2,  Low  Density 
           Residential.  According  to  the  General  Plan  and  San  Mateo  County  Assessor,  there  are  no 
           Williamson  Act  contracts  within  the  vicinity  of  the  project.  The  project  would  not  result  in  the 
           conversion of farmland to a nonagricultural use onsite and offsite because there is no farmland 
           within  the  project  site  or  in  the  vicinity.  Therefore,  implementation  of  the  project  would  not 
           impact agricultural resources. 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                        22                             Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                  June 2008 
                                                                              6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


6.3        Air Quality 

                                                                                         Less than 
                                                                          Potentially    Significant     Less than 
                                                                          Significant    with Project    Significant    No 
                                                                          Impact         Mitigation      Impact         Impact 
     
                                                                                                                         
    AIR  QUALITY    Where  available,  the  significance 
    criteria  established  by  the  applicable  air  quality 
    management  or  air  pollution  control  district  may  be 
    relied  upon  to  make  the  following  determinations. 
    Would the project: 

    a)  Conflict  with  or  obstruct  implementation  of  the 
                                                                                                                                
        applicable air quality plan? 

    b)  Violate  any  air  quality  standard  or  contribute 
        substantially  to  an  existing  or  projected  air  quality                                                            
        violation? 

    c)  Result in a cumulatively considerable net increase of 
        any  criteria  pollutant  for  which  the  project  region  is 
        nonattainment  under  an  applicable  federal  or  state 
                                                                                                                                
        ambient  air  quality  standard  (including  releasing 
        emissions,  which  exceed  quantitative  thresholds  for 
        ozone precursors)? 

    d)  Expose  sensitive  receptors  to  substantial  pollutant 
        concentrations? 
                                                                                                                                

    e)  Create  objectionable  odors  affecting  a  substantial 
                                                                                                                                
        number of people? 

 
DISCUSSION: 

a.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  The  Bay  Area  Air  Quality  Management  District  (BAAQMD) 
           prepares  air  quality  plans  based  on  population  projections  from  Association  of  Bay  Area 
           Governments  (ABAG)  and  development  projections  from  various  general  plans.  Therefore,  if  a 
           project  is  consistent  with  its  applicable  general  plan,  in  this  case  the  San  Bruno  General  Plan,  it 
           would  have  been  accounted  for  in  the  air  quality  plan  and  would  not  conflict  or  obstruct 
           implementation of the plan. 

           The  proposed  project  would  require  the  demolition  of  four  existing  commercial  buildings  and 
           parking  lot.  Following  demolition,  a  mixeduse  threestory  building  would  be  constructed.  The 
           proposed  project  would  include  15,000  square  feet  of  commercial  space,  48  residential  units,  and 
           152  parking  spaces.  The  project  site  is  currently  zoned  for  CBD  and  R2.  Therefore,  the 
           commercial  portion  of  the  proposed  project  would  be  consistent  with  the  General  Plan.  The 


Impact Sciences, Inc.                                         23                             Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                   June 2008 
                                                                             6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


           residential zoning would only allow for 42 units; however, the proposed project would provide 8 
           affordable  (moderateincome)  units  that  would  allow  an  additional  6  units  according  to  the 
           City's  density  bonus  program.  The  City's  density  bonus  program,  pursuant  to  the  California 
           density  bonus  law,  encourages  the  development  of  affordable  units.  The  proposed  commercial 
           and  residential  uses  would  be  consistent  with  the  San  Bruno  General  Plan  and  therefore  would 
           not  conflict  or  obstruct  with  implementation  of  the  applicable  air  quality  plan.  Therefore  the 
           project`s impact would be less than significant. 

b.         Less  than  Significant  Impact  with  Mitigation.  Development  of  the  proposed  project  would 
           involve  the  demolition  of  the  existing  San  Bruno  Cinema  building  along  with  two  commercial 
           buildings.  Construction  of  the  proposed  project  would  also  require  grading  of  the  project  site 
           following  demolition.  During  construction  of  the  proposed  project,  PM10  fugitive  dust  emissions 
           would  occur  due  to  earthmoving  and  grading  activities.  These  activities  have  the  potential  to 
           cause a shortterm significant impact with respect to air quality standards.  

           The  BAAQMD  emphasizes  the  importance  of  implementing  all  feasible  control  measures  during 
           construction  rather  than  quantification  of  construction  emissions.  Accordingly,  the  BAAQMD 
           CEQA  Guidelines  recommend  that  all  projects  implement  the  "basic"  fugitive  dust  control 
           measures from Table 2 of the BAAQMD CEQA Guidelines. For projects that would be greater than 
           4  acres  in  size  or  be  located  close  to  sensitive  receptors,  "enhanced"  and  "optional"  control 
           measures  are  also  recommended.  It  should  also  be  noted  that  emissions  of  carbon  monoxide 
           (CO)  and  ozone  precursors  are  considered  to  be  already  included  in  the  regional  air  quality  plan 
           and  are  not  expected  to  impede  attainment  or  maintenance  of  those  standards.  With 
           implementation  of  Mitigation  Measure  AIR1  (control  measures  recommended  by  the 
           BAAQMD),  the  proposed  project  would  not  violate  any  air  quality  standards.  Therefore,  the 
           proposed project's impact would be considered less than significant.  

           In  addition,  the  buildings  to  be  demolished  are  suspected  to  contain  asbestos  and  leadbased 
           paint.  The  BAAQMD,  in  addition  to  achieving  the  PM10  ambient  air  quality  standards,  is  also 
           concerned  with  asbestos  emissions  during  demolition  activities.  In  compliance  with  the 
           BAAQMD  regulations  for  asbestoscontaining  material  and  Mitigation  Measure  HAZ2  (in 
           Section 6.7), any building suspected of containing asbestos materials (ACMs) requires BAAQMD 
           review  and  authorization  prior  to  the  Building  Division  issuance  of  a  building  or  demolition 
           permit.  The  Building  Division  reviews  the  application  for  a  permit  and  requires  the  applicant  to 
           retain  the  services  of  a  licensed  and  certified  asbestos  inspector  to  perform  a  site  inspection  and, 
           if  necessary,  removal  of  all  ACMs.  The  applicant  is  referred  to  the  BAAQMD  for  removal 
           compliance  pursuant  to  the  BAAQMD  regulations.  The  City  does  not  issue  any  building  or 
           demolition  permits  until  the  applicant  returns  with  written  verification  from  BAAQMD  that 
           compliance  has  been  met.  With  full  implementation  of  this  requirement,  along  with  Mitigation 
           Measures  HAZ1  and  HAZ2,  the  proposed  project  would  reduce  potential  impacts  from 
           asbestos and leadbased paint to a less than significant level. 

           Mitigation  Measure  AIR1:  The  project  applicant  shall  ensure  that  the  following  measures  are 
           implemented during construction of the proposed project: 

           ·     Water all active construction surfaces at least twice daily; 
           ·     Cover  all  truck  hauling  soil,  sand,  and  other  loose  materials  or  require  all  trucks  to  maintain 
                 at least two feet of freeboard; 

Impact Sciences, Inc.                                          24                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                   June 2008 
                                                                           6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


           ·     Pave,  apply  water  three  times  daily,  or  apply  (nontoxic)  soil  stabilizers  on  all  unpaved 
                 access roads, parking areas and staging areas at construction sites; 
           ·     Sweep daily (with water sweepers) all paved access roads, parking areas and staging areas at 
                 construction sites; and 
           ·     Sweep  streets  daily  (with  water  sweepers)  if  visible  soil  material  is  carried  onto  adjacent 
                 public streets. 
c.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  Following  construction  of  the  proposed  project,  operational 
           emissions  would  be  generated  as  a  result  of  vehicle  trips  to  and  from  the  proposed  project.  Air 
           emissions  generated  from  these  trips  would  cumulatively  contribute  to  air  emissions  in  the 
           region.  However,  the  BAAQMD  CEQA  Guidelines  indicate  that  residential  developments 
           containing  fewer  than  320  singlefamily  units  or  510  apartments  are  not  likely  to  result  in  a 
           cumulatively  considerable  air  quality  impact.  In  addition,  the  Guidelines  identify  general  office 
           buildings  less  than  280,000  square  feet  as  not  being  likely  to  result  in  a  cumulative  considerable 
           air  quality  impact.  The  proposed  project  would  develop  land  uses  much  less  than  the  levels 
           identified  in  the  BAAQMD  CEQA  Guidelines;  therefore,  although  the  proposed  project  would 
           generate  air  emissions  in  the  region,  the  emissions  would  not  make  a  cumulatively  considerable 
           contribution to a cumulative impact on air quality.  

           In  addition,  the  BAAQMD  CEQA  Guidelines  recommend  thresholds  of  significance  for 
           operational  emissions  of  ROG  and  NOX.  Projects  that  would  generate  emissions  below  the 
           significance  thresholds  are  considered  not  to  cause  a  significant  impact  and  would  not  cause  a 
           cumulatively  considerable  impact  to  air  quality.  The  operational  emissions  associated  with  the 
           proposed  project  were  calculated  using  the  land  use  and  emissions  estimation  model, 
           URBEMIS2007  Version  9.2.2.  Trip  generation  values  were  obtained  from  the  traffic  study 
           prepared  by  DKS  Associates.  An  operational  year  of  2010  was  used  to  estimate  the  proposed 
           project's  operational  emissions.  Table  1,  Peninsular  Plaza  Estimated  Operational  Emissions  -- 
           Unmitigated,  presents  the  project's  operational  emissions  assuming  a  2010  buildout  year.  As 
           shown  below  in  Table  1,  the  project's  longterm  operational  emissions  of  ROG  and  NOX  would 
           not  exceed  the  BAAQMD  thresholds  of  significance.  Therefore,  the  proposed  project  would  not 
           make  a  cumulatively  considerable  contribution  to  a  cumulative  impact  on  air  quality  in  the 
           region.  




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                        25                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND

1  "Summertime Emissions" are representative of the conditions that may occur during the ozone season (May 1 to October 31). 

2  "Wintertime Emissions" are representative of the conditions that may occur during the balance of the year (November 1 to April 30). 

 
 
d.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  The  proposed  project  would  develop  residential  units  and 
           commercial  space.  The  proposed  project  would  not  operate  any  point  sources  that  would 
           generate substantial concentrations of pollutants. Emissions associated with the proposed project 
           would  primarily  be  from  vehicles.  Three  exhaust  fans  would  be  provided  in  the  underground 
           portion  of  the  parking  garage  to  maintain  circulation  and  avoid  a  buildup  of  vehicle  exhaust 
           emissions.  Vehicle  congestion  and  delay  at  intersections  could  lead  to  a  CO  hotspot  (violation  of 
           the  California  or  federal  ambient  air  quality  standard).  However,  the  maximum  background 
           concentration  registered  in  San  Mateo  County  (i.e.,  Redwood  City)  in  the  past  three  years  was 
           approximately  31  percent  of  the  state  8hour  standard.  Therefore,  it  is  unlikely  that  the  proposed 
           project's  traffic  would  cause  an  exceedance  of  the  standard  and  therefore,  the  project's  impact 
           would  be  considered  less  than  significant.  In  addition,  the  intersections  impacted  by  the 
           proposed  project's  traffic  would  all  operate  at  a  level  of  service  (LOS) 2  D  or  above.  Intersections 
           determined to operate at LOS E or F have the potential to cause a CO hotspot. Implementation of 
           the  proposed  project  would  not  degrade  the  LOS  of  any  impacted  intersection  below  D. 
           Therefore,  even  with  the  addition  of  the  proposed  project's  traffic,  intersections  would  not  be 
           affected  to  a  degree  where  CO  hotspots  could  occur.  Furthermore,  during  future  conditions,  all 
           affected  intersections  would  still  operate  at  LOS  D  and  above;  therefore,  the  project's  impact 
           would be considered less than significant.  

                                                           
2  Levels of Service (LOS) range from A (least congested) with a condition of free flow with low 
      volumes and high speeds to F (most congested) with stop and go, lowspeed conditions with little or 
      poor maneuverability. 

Impact Sciences, Inc.                                                 26                                 Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                               June 2008 
                                                                       6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


e.         Less  than  Significant  Impact.  The  proposed  project  would  include  residential  units  and 
           commercial  space.  These  are  not  typical  land  uses  associated  with  creating  objectionable  odors. 
           Any garbage or waste generated by the residential units or commercial uses will be collected and 
           disposed of according to the City requirements. In addition, odors could potentially be generated 
           during  shortterm  architectural  coating  activities.  However,  any  architectural  coatings  used  for 
           the  proposed  project  must  comply  with  the  requirements  of  BAAQMD  Regulation  8  Rule  3 
           Architectural  Coatings.  This  rule  limits  the  quantity  of  volatile  organic  compounds  (VOCs) 
           contained  in  architectural  coatings  sold,  used,  or  manufactured  within  the  District.  Compliance 
           with  Regulation  8  Rule  3  would  minimize  any  odor  impacts  from  architectural  coating 
           operations. Therefore, the project's impact would be considered less than significant.

6.4        Biological Resources

    BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES  Would the project: 

    a)  Have  a  substantial  adverse  effect,  either  directly  or 
        through  habitat  modifications,  on  any  species 
        identified  as  a  candidate,  sensitive,  or  special  status 
                                                                                                                                
        species  in  local  or  regional  plans,  policies,  or 
        regulations,  or  by  the  California  Department  of  Fish 
        and Game or U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service? 

    b)  Have  a  substantial  adverse  effect  on  any  riparian 
        habitat  or  other  sensitive  natural  community 
        identified  in  local  or  regional  plans,  policies,  and                                                             
        regulations  or  by  the  California  Department  of  Fish 
        and Game or U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service? 

    c)  Have  a  substantial  adverse  effect  on  federally 
        protected  wetlands  as  defined  by  Section  404  of  the 
        Clean  Water  Act  (including,  but  not  limited  to, 
        marsh,  vernal  pool,  coastal,  etc.)  through  direct 
                                                                                                                                
        removal,  filling,  hydrological  interruption,  or  other 
        means? 

    d)  Interfere  substantially  with  the  movement  of  any 
        native  resident  or  migratory  fish  or  wildlife  species 
        or  with  established  native  resident  or  migratory                                                                  
        wildlife  corridors,  or  impede  the  use  of  native 
        wildlife nursery sites? 

    e)  Conflict  with  any  local  policies  or  ordinances 
        protecting  biological  resources,  such  as  a  tree                                                                   
        preservation policy or ordinance? 

    f)  Conflict  with  the  provisions  of  an  adopted  Habitat 
        Conservation        Plan,     Natural        Community 
        Conservation  Plan,  or  other  approved  local, 
                                                                                                                                
        regional, or state habitat conservation plan? 

 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                         28                             Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                   June 2008 
                                                                             6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


DISCUSSION: 

a.         Less  than  Significant  Impact  with  Mitigation.  No  natural  habitats  or  vegetation  communities 
           currently exist on the site, and due to the area's long history of disturbance, it is unlikely that the 
           proposed  project  would  have  direct  or  indirect  adverse  effects  on  any  rare,  endangered,  or 
           threatened  species.  The  California  Natural  Diversity  Data  Base  (CNDDB)  does  document 
           occurrences  of  special  status  species  within  the  USGS  quadrangles  containing  or  adjacent  to  the 
           site,  but  many  of  these  are  historical  or  associated  with  sensitive  habitats  not  found  on  the  site 
           (California  Department  of  Fish  and  Game  [CDFG,  2007]).  Habitat  for  any  of  the  special  status 
           species  plant  or  animal  species  or  native  communities  listed  by  the  CNDDB  or  California  Native 
           Plant  Society  (2007)  no  longer  exists  at  the  project  site.  There  are  no  wetlands  on  the  property,  as 
           defined by either the federal Clean Water Act or the State or the State of California. A site survey 
           was  conducted  by  Impact  Sciences,  Inc.  on  August  28,  2007,  to  verify  existing  conditions,  assess 
           vegetation  and  wildlife  habitats,  and  identify  the  potential  for  sensitive  species  to  occur  onsite. 
           The  project  site  is  completely  developed  with  existing  structures  and  a  parking  lot.  Tree  species 
           occurring  on  the  project  site  include  pine  and  eucalyptus,  and  various  other  trees  planted  as 
           landscaping.  Given  the  urban  location  of  the  project  site,  the  scattered  location  of  the  existing 
           trees, and the fact that the site is not adjacent to an area providing foraging habitat, use of the on
           site trees as nesting habitat by specialstatus bird species is not expected. 


           However,  the  trees  on  the  project  site  provide  suitable  nesting  habitat  for  a  variety  of  common 
           bird  species  known  to  occur  in  the  project  area.  Constructionrelated  activities could result in the 
           direct  loss  of  active  nests  or  the  abandonment  of  active  nests  by  adult  birds  during  that  year's 
           nesting  season.  Bird  nests  with  eggs  or  young  are  protected  under  the  Migratory  Bird  Treaty  Act 
           and  the  California  Fish  and  Game  Code.  Mitigation  Measures  BIO1  through  BIO3,  applied  to 
           the  project  during  construction  activities  (that  could  disturb  nesting  birds),  would  reduce  the 
           potential impact to a less than significant level. 

           Mitigation  Measure  BIO1:  The  applicant  shall  retain  a  qualified  biologist  (with  selection  to  be 
           approved  by  the  City)  to  conduct  a  survey  on  the  site  prior  to  construction  or  site  preparation 
           activities  occurring  during  the  nesting/breeding  season  of  native  bird  species  (typically  February 
           through  August).  The  survey  area  shall  include  all  potential  nesting  habitat  on  the  project  site 
           and  within  200  feet  of  the  grading  boundaries.  If  the  200foot  distance  encompasses  trees  on 
           adjacent properties, the biologist shall survey the trees using binoculars. 

           The  survey  shall  be  conducted  no  more  than  14  days  prior  to  commencement  of  construction 
           activities. 

           Mitigation  Measure  BIO2:  If  active  nests  of  bird  species  protected  by  the Migratory Bird Treaty 
           Act and/or the California Fish and Game Code (which, together, apply to all native nesting birds) 
           are  present  in  the  construction  zone  or  within  200  feet  of  this  area,  temporary  construction 
           fencing shall be erected within the project site at a minimum of 100 feet around the nest site. This 
           temporary  buffer  may  be  greater  depending  on  the  bird  species  and  construction  activity,  as 
           determined by the biologist. 

           Mitigation  Measure  BIO3:  At  the  discretion  of  the  biologist,  clearing  and  construction  within 
           the fenced area shall be postponed or halted until juveniles have fledged and there is no evidence 
           of  a  second  nesting  attempt.  The  biologist  shall  serve  as  a  construction  monitor  during  those 


Impact Sciences, Inc.                                          29                             Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                    June 2008 
                                                                             6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


           periods  when  construction  activities  will  occur  near  active  nest  areas  to  ensure  that  no 
           inadvertent impacts on these nests will occur. 
b., c. d.  No  Impact.  The  site  is  completely  developed  and  does  not  contain  wetland  or  riparian  habitats. 
           The  project  site  is  completely  surrounded  by  residential  uses  to  the  east,  and  commercial  uses  to 
           the  north,  west,  and  south  and  therefore  does  not  provide  for  wildlife  movement  corridor  or  a 
           native wildlife nursery site. There would be no impact and no further analysis is required.  

e.         Less  than  Significant  Impact  with  Mitigation.  The  City  of  San  Bruno  has  adopted  a  Heritage 
           Tree  ordinance  to  preserve  the  urban  forest  and  protect  trees  that  are  significant  to  the 
           community. According to the San Bruno Municipal Code, a tree is considered a Heritage Tree if it 
           meets any of the following criteria: 

           ·     Any  native  Bay  (Umbellularia  californica),  Buckeye  (Aesculus  species),  Oak  (Quercus  species), 
                 Redwood  (Sequoia  sempervirens),  or  Pine  (Pinus  radiata)  tree  that  has  a  diameter  of  6  inches  or 
                 more measured at 54 inches above natural grade; 

           ·     Any  tree  or  stand  of  trees  designated  by  resolution  of  the  City  Council  to  be  of  special 
                 historical value or of significant community benefit; 

           ·     A stand of trees, the nature of which makes each dependent on the others for survival; or 

           ·      Any  other  tree  with  a  trunk  diameter  of  10  inches  or  more,  measured  at  54  inches  above 
                 natural grade. 

           The proposed project would remove six trees including two pine trees (8inch and 12inchtrunk 
           diameter),  two  eucalyptus  trees  (24  inch  and  30  inch  trunk  diameter),  and  two  ornamental  trees 
           of  unknown  size.  According  to  the  Heritage  Tree  Ordinance,  defined  above,  three  of  the  trees 
           would  be  classified  as  Heritage  Trees.  Removal  of  or  damage  is  to  Heritage  Trees  would  be  a 
           potentially  significant  impact.  In  order  to  remove  a  Heritage  Tree,  a  tree removal permit must be 
           obtained  from  the  San  Bruno  Director  of  Public  Works  and  conditions  stipulated  by  the  permit 
           must  be  followed.  Adherence  to  the  San  Bruno  Heritage  Tree  Ordinance  and  implementation  of 
           Mitigation Measure BIO4 would reduce impacts to a less than significant level.  

           Mitigation  Measure  BIO4:  To  the  extent  possible,  project  design  should  avoid  removal  and 
           damage to Heritage Trees. For any Heritage Tree to be removed, a Heritage Tree Removal Permit 
           must  be  obtained  from  the  City  of  San  Bruno  before  a  Heritage  Tree  is  removed.  As  determined 
           by  the  City  of  San  Bruno  a  minimum  of  two  15inch  box  size  trees  shall  be  required  to  mitigate 
           the loss of each Heritage Tree. 

f.         No  Impact.  The  project  site  is  not  within  any  Habitat  Conservation  Plan,  Natural  Community 
           Conservation  Plan,  or  any  other  state,  regional,  or  local  conservation  plan  area.  Therefore,  no 
           impact would occur. 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                          30                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                   June 2008 
                                                                            6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


6.5        Cultural Resources 

                                                                                       Less than 
                                                                        Potentially    Significant     Less than 
                                                                        Significant    with Project    Significant    No 
                                                                        Impact         Mitigation      Impact         Impact 
     
                                                                                                                       
    CULTURAL RESOURCES  Would the project: 

    a)  Cause a substantial adverse change in the 
        significance of a historical resource as defined in                                                                   
        §15064.5? 

    b)  Cause  a  substantial  adverse  change  in  the 
        significance  of  an  archaeological  resource  pursuant                                                              
        to §15064.5? 

    c)  Directly  or  indirectly  destroy  a  unique 
        paleontological  resource  or  site  or  unique  geologic                                                             
        feature? 

    d)  Disturb  any  human  remains,  including  those 
        interred outside of formal cemeteries 
                                                                                                                              


DISCUSSION: 

a.         Less than Significant Impact.   The  proposed  project  would  involve  the  demolition  and 
           redevelopment  of  an  existing  parking  lot  and  three  commercial  buildings.  A  historic  resource 
           evaluation was completed for the El Camino Theater by Kent L. Seavey. The report is included in 
           Appendix  B  of  this  document.  The  project  site  currently  contains  the  former  El  Camino  Theater 
           (Theater).  The  Theater  opened  in  1930  and  was  built  with  art  deco  architectural  details.  Historic 
           photographs  from  the  1940s  show  a  neon  marquee  above  the  recessed  entry  area.  The  entrance 
           was  flanked  by  two  retail  shops  with  large  plate  glass  windows.  A  photograph  from  1967  shows 
           a  vertical  neon  fin  above  the  neon  marquee,  in  the  art  deco  style.  The  Theater  remained  in 
           operation  until  the  1970s.  A  remodel  of  the  Theater  in  1978  removed  the  exterior  fin  above  the 
           marquee.  The  Theater  underwent  a  series  of  remodels  that  heavily  altered  the  exterior  and 
           interior through 2004, leaving the building in its current state.  

           According  to  the  historic  resource  evaluation,  the  Theater  was  a  visible  centerpiece  along  El 
           Camino  Real  and  drew  patrons  to  the  commercial  core  of  San  Bruno.  The  unique  art  deco 
           features  that  characterized  the  Theater  for  its  patrons  are  no  longer  present.  Key  historical 
           features  that  the  building  has  lost  include  the  marquee,  neon  fin,  and  recessed  entry  with  ticket 
           booth.  The  shaped  parapet  wall  fronting  El  Camino  Real  is  all  that  remains  of  the  historical 
           façade features.  

           Although  the  building  is  more  than  50  years  old,  the  modifications  that  have  occurred  since  the 
           1970s have removed most of the original art deco architectural components from the Theater. The 
           site  is  not  included  on  the  National  or  California  Register  of  Historical  Places.  In  addition,  the 


Impact Sciences, Inc.                                        31                            Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                                 June 2008 
                                                                        6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


           Theater  is  not  included  in  the  California  Office  of  Historic  Preservationmaintained  "Historic 
           Property  Data  Files  for  San  Mateo  County,"  or  any  San  Bruno  or  San  Mateo  County  historic 
           resource  inventories.  The  Theater  does not meet the necessary criteria for listing in the California 
           Register  of  Historical  Resources.  Therefore,  the  property  cannot  be  considered  an  historic 
           resource and the impact from the removal of this building is considered less than significant.  

b., c., d. Less  than  Significant  Impact  with  Mitigation.  The  project  site  is  currently  developed  with  four 
           commercial  structures  and  a  surface  parking  lot.  Prior  construction  activities  would  have 
           resulted  in  the  discovery  and  either  curation  or  destruction  of  nearsurface  archaeological 
           resources or human remains, if any were present onsite. The proposed project would include the 
           demolition of the existing structures and surface parking lot and the construction of a threestory 
           commercial/residential  building. It is probable that construction activities, including grading and 
           excavation, would extend to depths greater than those required for the current structures. This in 
           turn  would  result  in  the  potential  for  the  discovery  of  archaeological  (including  human  remains) 
           or  paleontological  resources  below  levels  of  prior  disturbance.  Based  on  the  Historical  Resource 
           Inventory  prepared  for  the  San  Bruno  Redevelopment  Project,  there  is  a  low  probability  of 
           encountering human remains during construction activities. If any unrecorded cultural resources 
           are  uncovered  during  project  construction  activities,  the  following  mitigation  measure  would  be 
           implemented in order to reduce the impact to less than significant level.  

           Mitigation  Measure  CULT1:  If  archeological  or  paleontological  materials  are  identified,  work 
           on  that  portion  of  the  project  shall  cease  until  a  resource  protection  plan  conforming  to  CEQA 
           Section 15064.5 is prepared by a qualified archeologist or paleontologist and approved by the San 
           Bruno  Community  Development  Director  or  authorized  representative.  Project  work  may  be 
           resumed  in  compliance  with  such  plan.  If  human  remains  are  encountered,  the  County  Coroner 
           shall be contacted immediately and the provisions of State law carried out. 




Impact Sciences, Inc.                                      32                           Peninsular Project Initial Study/MND 
0944001                                                                                                              June 2008 
                                                                                 6.0  Evaluation of Environmental Impacts 


6.6        Geology and Soils 

                                                                                            Less than 
                                                                             Potentially    Significant      Less than 
                                                                             Significant    with Project     Significant    No 
                                                                             Impact         Mitigation       Impact         Impact 
     
                                                                                                                             
    GEOLOGY AND SOILS  Would the project: 
                                                                                                                             
    a)  Expose  people  or  structures  to  potential  substantial 
        adverse  effects,  including  the  risk  of  loss,  injury,  or 
        death involving: 

    i)  Rupture  of  a  known  earthquake  fault,  as  delineated 
        on  the  most  recent  AlquistPriolo  Earthquake  Fault 
        Zoning  Map  issued  by  the  State  Geologist  for  the 
                                                                                                                                    
        area  or  based  on  other  substantial  evidence  of  a 
        known  fault?  Refer  to  Division  of  Mines  and 
        Geology Special Publication 42. 

    ii)  Strong seismic ground shaking?                                                                                             

    iii)  Seismicrelated        ground         failure,      including 
                                                                                                                                    
          liquefaction? 

    iv)  Landslides?                                                                                                                

    b)  Result  in  substantial  soil  erosion  or  the  loss  of 
                                                                                                                                    
        topsoil? 

    c)  Be  located  on  a  geologic  unit  or  soil  that  is  unstable, 
        or  that  would  become  unstable  as  a  result  of  the 
        project,  and  potentially  result  in  on  or  offsite                                                                     
        landslide, lateral spreading, subsidence, liquefaction 
        or collapse? 

    d)  Be  located  on  expansive  soil,  as  defined  in 
        Table 181B  of  the  Uniform  Building  Code  (1994),
